channel.title: Any other Suse fans?
channel.description: I have been using Fedora off and on for a while now until recently when I read a article on OpenSuse and I gave it a try. I am surprised to say that its everything I need right out of the box which doesn't happen too much. No major problems I can think of, so yeah.. Any other fans out there or people currently using it?

item.title: Any other Suse fans?
item.dc:creator: @Wizzup Wizzup?
item.description:
@Wizzup wrote:

Haven’t really used Suse. I can’t say I’m a fan of their package manager, not of apt. Although apt is OK for its simplicity.

Portage is obviously the superior package manager out there…
So it’s all Gentoo, really.

Hostname: nala - OS: Linux 2.6.39.4-vs2.3.1-pre9.2-the-princess-is-in-another-castle/x86_64 - Distro: Gentoo 2.0.3 - CPU: 8 x Intel Xeon (2667.000 MHz) - Processes: 111 - Uptime: 28d 18h 15m - Users: 6 - Load Average: 0.00 - Memory Usage: 892.13MB/24158.50MB (3.69%) - Disk Usage: 68.02GB/9221.23GB (0.74%) (Disk usage is off because of mount -o bind I think)

Hostname: sheeva - OS: Linux 2.6.39-gentoo-r3Shizzup/armv5tel - Distro: Gentoo 2.0.3 - CPU: Feroceon 88FR131 rev 1 (v5l) (1191.11 MHz) - Processes: 114 - Uptime: 45d 20h - Users: 6 - Load Average: 0.20 - Memory Usage: 265.34MB/500.60MB (53.00%) - Disk Usage: 2596.84GB/5501.60GB (47.20%)

item.title: Any other Suse fans?
item.dc:creator: @newguy45 newguy45
item.description:
@newguy45 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:7, topic:420261”][quote author=newguy45 link=topic=522815.msg3803208#msg3803208 date=1320224781]
I remember using it in Linux server administration. I was not a big fan of its package manager however, it may had been just because the whole concept was new to me at the time, I personally am loving centOS for my linux server needs, yum ( package manager ) is really simple to use and is pretty fast.
[/quote]

I thought CentOS, Redhat, and SuSe all used the same package manager?

I’ve used it too, but I am too much of a fan of apt and dpkg to go to an RPM-based distro.[/quote]

Suse uses YAST whereas Centos uses yum, at least Suse used to use YAST

Read full topic

item.title: Any other Suse fans?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

newguy45:

I remember using it in Linux server administration. I was not a big fan of its package manager however, it may had been just because the whole concept was new to me at the time, I personally am loving centOS for my linux server needs, yum ( package manager ) is really simple to use and is pretty fast.

I thought CentOS, Redhat, and SuSe all used the same package manager?

I’ve used it too, but I am too much of a fan of apt and dpkg to go to an RPM-based distro.

Read full topic
